awd_titl_txt: IUCRC Evaluation Project: Model Redesign & Development
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Centers (I/UCRC) is considered the longest operating partnership-based center program supported by NSF.  I/UCRCs bring industry and universities together to conduct cutting edge research that drives innovation and US competitive advantage. A key element of the I/UCRC Program, and one that is believed to have contributed to its success, is its commitment to a systematic and objective evaluation effort that provides value to both the NSF and to local centers. The project seeks to promote the progress of science by objectively evaluating and documenting the impact of I/UCRCs in order to provide the NSF with actionable, timely, data-based feedback, analysis and advice on the funded centers; and to identify and communicate I/UCRC best practices to NSF. Research and evaluation conducted through the I/UCRC Evaluation Project in the past has made a significant contribution to a broadened understanding of cooperative research in general and industry/university centers in particular.  Our work has been a pioneer in exploring important new constructs including ?unintended consequences? of cooperative research, cost-avoidance benefits of membership, organizational commitment of center faculty and program sustainability of cooperative research centers. The project has also succeeded in being a training vehicle for the next generation of science and technology evaluators by promoting high quality research opportunities for the graduate students supported by the project.  
The proposed I/UCRC Evaluation Project addresses both accountability and improvement evaluation issues and involves both program-level and center-level elements. The accountability-driven element of the I/UCRC evaluation strategy focuses on collecting and reporting data on center and program-level inputs, outputs, outcomes and impacts. The improvement-oriented element of the I/UCRC evaluation strategy focuses on providing relatively real-time feedback on collected data to NSF (and local centers) to aid improvement and document best practices.  The evaluation effort reports to NSF and involves collection of data on I/UCRC inputs, outputs, outcomes and impacts. We will address a number of new evaluation issues including integration of program-level data collection and databases with NSF internal efforts, and other support for the development of the NSF?s new I/UCRC evaluation model. The center-level evaluation depends on a team of on-site assessment coordinators who collect data at their site and provide feedback on their findings to the NSF. We will provide data analysis and reporting of this data for national benchmarking and other purposes.

por.por_cntn:
The Industry University Cooperative Research Centers (IUCRC) Program is NSF's oldest operating partnerships-based program,  and continues to play an important roll in the US innovation ecosystem.  Since 1979, the NSF has launched 200 IUCRCs, with over 1500 sites at over 180 universities, and an estimated 3500 industry and government member organizations. One of the most unique aspects of the IUCRC Program has been its continuous commitment to independent, improvement-oriented evaluation. While the nature and the structure of the evaluation has evolved over time, it has retained a focus on both evaluation for accountability and improvement. Structural components of the IUCRC evaluation model include: a methodologically rigorous, program-wide evaluation of IUCRC outputs, outcomes and impacts; evaluation of and feedback to individual centers by embeded evaluators; and national coordination of the local evaluation effort to ensure that these activities contribute to the goals of the overall evaluation. Since 1986, the IUCRC Evaluation Project at North Carolina State University has developed, refined, and coordinated the IUCRC evaluation model in support of two goals:  to contribute to an understanding of the operations and outcomes of IUCRCs and similar cooperative research programs; and to help improve center and program operations and performance by providing timely, data-based  evaluation feedback about center processes and outcomes.

Annually collected data and targeted evaluation studies  conducted over the course of this award have helped identify operational best practices for IUCRCs. For instance, centers that provide their students with erperiential reasearch opportunities and network connections are more likely to achieve important education and workforce development outcomes.  In addition to identifing and disseminating best practices for IURCRs, the Evaluation Project has also documented center efficacy in terms of education and workforce development, leveraging of federal funding, and improving member firm R&D efficacy and technology translation, ultimately leading to significant measureable economic impacts.  Over the last ten years, more than 7000 degrees have been awarded to students trained in IUCRCs. Those students go on to pursue careers in industry, academia and government, with nearly half taking industry jobs, almost a third of which are with member firms. In terms of leveraged investment, for every dollar the NSF IUCRC Program has invested in centers over the last 10 years, those funds have been leveraged 1:5 against funds contributed to the centers from industry and other sources.  Impressively, for every $1 invested by the average center member, that member gets access to $42 worth of center research. As a result of these leveraged investments over the last eight years, center members have reported $1.75 Billion in research cost avoidance and over $300 Million in research cost savings.  Over that same period, center research has stimulated a reported $391 Million in follow-on research within member firms and has spawned 69 spinoff companies.

At the same time, the IUCRC Evaluation Project at North Carolina State University has built on its 30+ year history of pioneering improvement-focused CRC evaluation methods and scholarship. With direction from the NSF and invaluable input from the embedded evaluators, the NC State team has played a central leadership role in ensuring that the IUCRC evaluation is theoretically Informed and methodologically rigorous. The archival database built under this and subsequent awards, which includes annual data on all funded IUCRCs over nearly the entire life of the IUCRC Program, has enabled numerous social science publications, theses, and dissertations. As the IUCRC Program evolves new evaluation methods, metrics, and data sources will be required to continue to support program growth and success.
